item.title: GTA Online Will Let You Get Abducted By Aliens To Earn Cool Reward
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/gta-online-will-let-you-get-abducted-by-alien-to-earn-cool-reward/1100-6527553/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Halloween may be over, but as they say on The X-Files, the truth is out there in Grand Theft Auto Online. Alien abductions are still taking place in Los Santos, and you're going want to be among the abductees if you'd like to get a cool weapon. But players are going to need to act fast, because these visitors from another world won't be hanging around forever.

Rockstar Games announced the alien abduction for this year's Halloween events, and it's going on through November 6. That means the skies are still strange, and players who make it out alive can earn The Shocker, a non-lethal alien weapon that acts like a stun baton. The hard part, however, might be getting captured in the first place.

The first thing that you need to know is that the aliens only come out at night from 10 PM to 4 AM in the game world, and given GTA Online's fast movement of time, this means that there's only a 12-minute window to find a UFO ship and get under it. Another complication is that your vehicles will fail if they get too close to the UFOs, so plan accordingly.

If you've successfully pulled off the abduction, the next step is escape. Players will find themselves locked in a room under Fort Zancudo. That's where The Shocker can be found, but players still have to get out with their lives in order to keep it. Opening the exit requires some close examinations of the clues in the chamber. Fortunately, The Gaming Gorilla has shared a video that breaks down how to get out of the room before a lethal gas makes this a one-way trip.

If you miss your opportunity to get abducted this year, it's likely that Rockstar will revisit the idea in time for Halloween 2025. But for now, you only have until Wednesday, November 6 to pull off what may be the spookiest mission in the game to date.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: This Elder Scrolls Game Is Ending Development, Servers Going Offline
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/this-elder-scrolls-game-is-ending-development-servers-going-offline/1100-6527552/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Free-to-play card game The Elder Scrolls Legends is no longer available to purchase on Steam and its servers will be switched off on January 30, 2025.

"Thank you for playing and we hope you have enjoyed your time in Legends," the game's Steam page (via Rock Paper Shotgun) reads. Set in the same fantasy world as the mainline Elder Scrolls games, The Elder Scrolls Legends launched back in 2017 and was one of several mobile games released by Bethesda back then, alongside the likes of Fallout Shelter and The Elder Scrolls: Blades.

Active development on The Elder Scrolls Legend ended in 2019, but there were still regular events and rewards for dedicated players. There have been several high-profile live-service game cancellations over the last couple of years, with one of the more notable being Sony's hero shooter Concord. After less than two weeks on sale, the game was taken offline and was permanently sunset in October, while developer Firewalk Studios was closed down.

Meanwhile, Bethesda released The Elder Scrolls: Castles on iOS and Android in September. Similar to Fallout Shelter, this game gives players their own castle to manage, allowing them to run their kingdom and repel invaders from inside of their personal fortress.

The Elder Scrolls 6 is also in development, but don't expect to see it for several more years. Back in 2023, Bethesda boss Todd Howard pondered about the very early announcement of The Elder Scrolls 6, and Bethesda veteran Bruce Nesmith said in a recent interview that it will be "almost impossible" for The Elder Scrolls 6 to live up the hype when it is eventually released.

Darryn Bonthuys on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
